title: 113_hr5703
content: The "Protect and Preserve International Cultural Property Act" defines cultural property and establishes the appropriate congressional committees. Congress finds that protecting international cultural property is crucial for US cultural diplomacy, as it shows respect for other cultures and the common heritage of humanity. Instances of cultural property being lost, damaged, or destroyed due to various threats are highlighted, such as the ransacking of museums in Egypt, looting in Iraq after Saddam Hussein's fall, and damage in Syria due to civil war. These events have resulted in the destruction and loss of significant ancient artifacts, impacting humanity's historical record. In Syria, Iraq, and Mali, cultural sites and artifacts have been destroyed or looted due to conflicts and terrorist activities. This includes damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites, destruction of cultural sites by ISIS/ISIL, and destruction of tombs and shrines in Timbuktu by Ansar Dine. Many ancient artifacts remain unrecovered, impacting humanity's historical record. In Timbuktu, Ansar Dine destroyed tombs and shrines, threatening ancient manuscripts. In Afghanistan, the Taliban destroyed the Bamiyan Buddhas, leading to global condemnation. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge systematically destroyed Buddhist temples, statues, and literature. In China, the Cultural Revolution resulted in the destruction of antiques and parts of old Beijing. In Haiti, the 2010 earthquake destroyed art. China's antiques were destroyed, including parts of old Beijing. Chinese authorities are now rebuilding lost architectural heritage. In Haiti, the 2010 earthquake destroyed art, artifacts, and archives, partially damaging the 17th century city of Jacmel. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami affected eleven countries, causing massive loss of life and damaging UNESCO World Heritage Sites like Mahabalipuram in India and the Old Town of Galle in Sri Lanka. The destruction of cultural properties represents an irreparable loss of humanity's heritage. The United States Armed Forces have played important roles in preserving cultural property since 1943. The United States Armed Forces have played a crucial role in preserving cultural property since 1943. President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas during World War II. The Monuments Men, part of the MFAA teams, secured and returned art stolen by the Nazis. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was founded in 2006 to support the protection of cultural property in armed conflicts. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield, established in 2006, supports the protection of international cultural property in armed conflicts and disasters. The United States policy aims to preserve cultural property at risk and fulfill obligations under the 1954 Hague Convention. The United States aims to protect cultural property in armed conflicts and disasters by preventing the importation of pillaged or stolen artifacts and enforcing existing laws to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property. SEC. 4. WHITE HOUSE COORDINATOR FOR INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY PROTECTION. The President appoints a White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection to coordinate efforts among federal agencies, submit annual reports to Congress, provide policy recommendations, resolve interagency differences, and collaborate with domestic and international entities. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection collaborates with various domestic and international actors to promote and protect cultural property. SEC. 5. INFORMATION ON ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY. The Secretary of State must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities under the Hague Convention and actions taken in conflicts involving the US. Additionally, details on protection efforts under other statutes, agreements, or policies must be included. The Administrator of USAID and the Secretary of Defense must provide information to the White House Coordinator on their efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities, coordination with other agencies, organizations, and programs to safeguard cultural property at risk from various threats. The Secretary of Defense and the Attorney General must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including directives, policies, regulations, and actions taken to safeguard cultural property at risk from destruction due to various threats. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including statutes and regulations employed in criminal actions to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property and actions taken to ensure consistent application of law in cases related to cultural property. Federal agencies can partner with the Smithsonian Institution for international cultural property protection activities, allowing personnel from the Smithsonian to assist in such efforts. Agencies are authorized to cover salaries and expenses for this collaboration, supporting missions related to military, diplomacy, and law enforcement. The Secretary of State is authorized to make grants for international cultural property protection activities in areas at risk of destruction. Additionally, emergency protection for Syrian cultural property is also addressed. The President will apply import restrictions to archaeological or ethnological material of Syria as if Syria were a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act. The restrictions apply to cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria after August 18, 2011, and will take effect within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. The term "State Party" in the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act refers to the country of Syria, where import restrictions will be applied to cultural property unlawfully removed after August 18, 2011.
